Our most interesting results included three SNPs in the TPH1 gene and one SNP in the SLC6A4 gene, which showed a significant association at a single locus when fluoxetine response was compared to nonresponse (P = 0.02-0.04). All odds ratios indicated an increased risk of non-response to fluoxetine. In the specific response versus indeterminate and nonresponse comparison, three SNPs in the TPH2 gene (P = 0.02-0.04) were positively associated and one SNP in the HTR2A gene (P = 0.02) was negatively associated. When comparing a specific response to a non-specific response, we found significant negative associations in three SNPs in the HTR2A gene (P = 0.001-0.03) and two SNPs in the MAOA gene (P = 0.03-0.05). We observed a variant, despite strong LD, in each gene and unexpectedly low numbers of estimated haplotypes, which consisted of tagged polymorphisms. Significant haplotype associations were found in all genes except HTR1A and HTR2C. Although these data should be interpreted with caution given the small sample size, these results suggest the involvement of TPH1 and SLC6A4 in the general response, and HTR2A, TPH2 and MAOA in the specificity of response to fluoxetine. Interestingly, we note that a number of less frequent alleles of several SNP markers were associated with non-responsive and indeterminate phenotypes.

The serotonin transporter is the molecular target of many antidepressants, and the gene (SLC6A4) that encodes this protein has been associated with response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). We sought to test the hypothesis that SLC6A4 is associated with SSRI response by re-identifying this gene in subjects with major depression. All exons, portions of all introns, and the promoter region containing the polymorphic repeat polymorphism (HTTLPR) polymorphism previously associated with SSRI response were sequenced for 96 subjects, and variants were tested for association with response to treatment with fluoxetine. We screened a total of 712 kilobases of sequence and found 27 SLC6A4 variants, 21 of which had not been previously described. Seventeen were seen on one chromosome each, including three of the five exonic variants. A polymorphism (rs25531), upstream of the HTTLPR, showed evidence of an association with response to treatment, and biochemical experiments showed that this polymorphism alters the binding of nuclear extracts to a consensus sequence of activating protein transcription factor 2, which is thought to be a transcription factor. A critical factor in the regulation of neuronal gene expression in mammals. These results support an association between response to SSRIs and deoxyribonucleic acid variation at the serotonin transporter locus. We have also identified an important functional variant potentially contributing to this association and a potential biological mechanism that could mediate its effect.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by repetitive, intrusive, disturbing thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors or mental actions that a person feels driven to do (compulsions). OCD has a partly genetic basis. To treat OCD, strong serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) medications (clomipramine (Anafranil), fluvoxamine (Luvox), fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and paroxetine (Paxil)) are used, which act on the serotonin transport protein. Uniquely effective. A polymorphism in the promoter region of the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein has recently been reported to affect protein expression and be associated with measures of anxiety, depression, and autism (using a family-controlled transmission disequilibrium test (TDT) design). . SLC6A4 thus has strong prior support for a potential impact on OCD risk: the protein it encodes is a drug target; Polymorphisms in the gene affect function; Polymorphisms have been shown to be associated with behavioral patterns. We used TDT with a cohort of 34 European-American triplet families, 30 unrelated and four derived from extended pedigrees, to test for linkage disequilibrium between OCD and alleles at a polymorphic locus of the SLC6A4 promoter. Of the 35 heterozygous parents, 24 transmitted the SLC6A4 'l' allele and 11 transmitted the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 4.83; P < 0.03). Considering only the 13 SRI non-responders, there were 13 heterozygous parents, of whom 10 carried the 'l' allele and three the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 3.77; P < 0.052). These data provide preliminary support for linkage disequilibrium and association between the SLC6A4 'l' allele and OCD.

Recent major findings from studies of SLC6A4 and its counterpart protein, serotonin (5-HT) transporter (SERT) in humans, rodents and non-human primates indicate that combinations of SLC6A4 non-coding 5', 3' UTRs and intronic regions as well as coding variants that act together can Altered 5HT transport by up to 40-fold in vitro. In vivo, SLC6A4 variants in humans and other species lead to marked physiological changes, despite attenuation of neurodevelopmental adaptations in 5-HT receptors as well as compensatory alterations in 5-HT synthesis and metabolism. Polymorphisms in SLC6A4 are associated with differences in emotional, endocrine, and personality characteristics as well as several diseases. This gene, in combinations with gene × gene (G × G) and gene × environment (G × E) interactions, is still not fully understood, with some association results remaining controversial. Given their fundamental importance in the regulation and function of the entire serotonergic system (as demonstrated by the consequences of inhibition of SERT reuptake by SSRIs such as fluoxetine in humans and transgenic changes in mice and rats), it seems likely that SLC6A4 and SERT will remain areas of great interest in attempts to Our field is to better understand and treat 5-HT related disorders.

Abacavir hypersensitivity reaction is strongly associated with the presence of the HLA-B*5701 allele. This study was designed to determine the potential effectiveness of screening for HLA-B*5701 to prevent hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. This randomized, double-blind study included 1,956 patients from 19 countries who were infected with HIV type 1 and who had not previously received abacavir. We randomly assigned patients to undergo prospective HLA-B*5701 screening, excluding HLA-B*5701-positive patients from abacavir treatment (prospective screening group), or to undergo the standard-of-care approach to abacavir without potential HLA-B*5701 screening (prospective screening group). Controller). All patients started on abacavir were observed for 6 weeks. To immunologically confirm and enhance the specificity of the clinical diagnosis of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir, we performed an epicutaneous patch test with abacavir. The prevalence of HLA-B*5701 was 5.6% (109 of 1956 patients). Among patients receiving abacavir, 72% were men, 84% were white, and 18% had never received antiretroviral therapy. Screening eliminated immunologically confirmed hypersensitivity reaction (0% in the potential screening group vs. 2.7% in the control group, P<0.001), with a negative predictive value of 100% and a positive predictive value of 47.9%. Hypersensitivity reaction was clinically diagnosed in 93 patients, with a significantly lower incidence in the potential screening group (3.4%) compared with the control group (7.8%) (P < 0.001). HLA-B*5701 testing reduces the risk of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. In predominantly white populations, similar to those in this study, 94% of patients do not carry the HLA-B*5701 allele and are at low risk for a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. Our results show that pharmacogenetic testing can be used to prevent a specific toxic effect of a drug. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00340080.)

The use of abacavir - a potent inhibitor of HIV-1 nucleoside reverse transcriptase - is complicated by a potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome in approximately 5% of cases. Genetic factors that influence the immune response to abacavir may confer susceptibility. We aimed to find associations between MHC alleles and abacavir hypersensitivity in HIV-1-infected individuals treated with abacavir. MHC region typing was performed in the first 200 participants in a Western Australian HIV cohort study exposed to abacavir. Significant hypersensitivity to abacavir was identified in 18 cases and was ruled out in 167 individuals exposed to the drug for more than 6 weeks (abacavir tolerant). 15 people had some symptoms but did not meet the criteria for abacavir hypersensitivity. p values ​​were corrected for comparisons between multiple HLA alleles (p(c)) by multiplying the raw p value by the estimated number of HLA alleles present within the locus examined. HLA-B*5701 was present in 14 (78%) of 18 patients with abacavir hypersensitivity, and in four (2%) of 167 abacavir-tolerant patients (OR 117 [95% CI 29-481], p(c (<0.0001), and the combination of HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 was found in 13 (72%) of hypersensitive and five (3%) of tolerant patients (73 [20-268], p(c)<0.0001). HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 were combined in 13 (72%) of the hypersensitive patients and none of the tolerant patients (822 [43-15675], p(c)<0.0001) Other MHC markers also present on the ancestral haplotype 57.1 to which the above three markers belong confirmed the presence of the haplotype-specific linkage defect, and mapped potential susceptibility loci to a region bounded by C4A6 and HLA-C within the entire abacavir-exposed group (n=200). Because HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 have a positive predictive value for hypersensitivity of 100%, and a negative predictive value of 97%, genetic susceptibility to abacavir hypersensitivity is determined by the ancestral haplotype 57.1 in our population, withholding abacavir in... Patients with HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 reduced the prevalence of hypersensitivity from 9% to 2.5% without depriving any patients of inappropriate use of abacavir.

Hypersensitivity to abacavir affects about 4% of patients receiving the drug for treatment of HIV-1 infection. We performed a retrospective case-control study to identify multiple peri-HLA-B markers associated with hypersensitivity reactions. HLA-B57 was present in 39 (46%) of 84 patients versus four (4%) of 113 controls (P < 0 small median point 0001). However, because of the lower numbers of women and other ethnic groups enrolled, these results largely relate to white men. The lower sensitivity of HLA-B57 for predicting abacavir hypersensitivity identified in this study compared to a previous report highlights that the predictive values ​​of markers will vary between populations. Clinical monitoring and management of hypersensitivity reactions in patients receiving abacavir should remain unchanged.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) are highly polymorphic proteins that initiate immunity by presenting pathogen-derived peptides to T cells. HLA polymorphisms predominantly map to the antigen-binding cleft, thus diversifying the repertoire of self- and pathogen-derived peptide antigens selected by different HLA allotypes. An increasing number of immune-based drug reactions, including abacavir hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) and carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), are associated with specific HLA alleles. However, little is known about the underlying mechanisms of these associations, including AHS, a typical HLA-linked drug reaction that occurs exclusively in individuals with the common histocompatibility allele HLA-B*57:01, and with a relative risk greater than 1,000. (Refs 6, 7). We have shown that unmodified abacavir binds non-covalently to HLA-B*57:01, lying across the bottom of the antigen-binding cleft and into the F pocket, where the carboxy-terminal tryptophan normally stabilizes HLA-B*57:01-binding peptides. . Abacavir binds with remarkable specificity to HLA-B*57:01, altering the conformation and chemistry of the antigen-binding cleft, thereby altering the repertoire of endogenous peptides that can bind HLA-B*57:01. In this way, abacavir directs the selection of new endogenous peptides, leading to a marked change in the “immune self.” The peptide-centered “variable self” activates abacavir-specific T cells, leading to polyclonal CD8 T cell activation and systemic reaction manifested as AHS. We also show that carbamazepine, a widely used antiepileptic drug associated with hypersensitivity reactions in HLA-B*15:02 individuals, binds to this variant, resulting in changes in the repertoire of presented endogenous peptides. Our findings simultaneously highlight the importance of HLA polymorphisms in evolving pharmacogenomics and provide a general mechanism for some of the increasing number of HLA-associated hypersensitivities involving small molecule drugs.

Progress in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, especially with regard to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, requires regular updating of concepts and management. A European LeukemiaNet expert panel reviewed previous and new studies to update recommendations made in 2009. We recommend imatinib, nilotinib, or dasatinib as first-line treatment. Response is assessed using real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction and/or cytogenetics at 3, 6, and 12 months. BCR-ABL1 transcript levels ≥10% at 3 months, <1% at 6 months, and ≥0.1% from 12 months onwards define optimal response, while >10% at 6 months and >1% at 12 months onwards define Failure, and this requires a change in treatment. Likewise, partial cytogenetic response (PCyR) at 3 months and complete cytogenetic response (CCyR) from 6 months onward define optimal response, whereas no CyR (Philadelphia chromosome positive [Ph+] > 95%) at 3 months, less PCyR at 6 months, and less than CCyR from 12 months onwards define failure. Between optimum and failure, there is an intermediate warning zone that requires more frequent monitoring. Similar definitions are provided for response to second-line treatment. Specific recommendations are made for patients with advanced stages and tumors, and for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Optimal responders should continue treatment indefinitely, with close monitoring, or may be enrolled in controlled studies to discontinue treatment once a deeper molecular response has been achieved.

Although the role of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in embryogenesis is well established, its functions in adult tissue regeneration and maintenance remain unclear, and the relationship of these functions to cancer development has not been determined. Here we show that loss of Smooth (Smo), an essential component of the Hh pathway, impairs hematopoietic stem cell regeneration and reduces induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) by the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Loss of Smo depletes CML stem cells—the cells that spread leukemia—while constitutively active Smo increases the number of CML stem cells and accelerates the disease. As a potential mechanism of Smo action, we show that the cell fate determinant Numb, which depletes CML stem cells, is increased in the absence of Smo activity. Moreover, pharmacological inhibition of Hh signaling attenuates not only the proliferation of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) driven by wild-type BCR-ABL1, but also the growth of imatinib-resistant mice and human CML. These data indicate that Hh pathway activity is required for maintenance of normal and tumorigenic stem cells in the hematopoietic system and raise the possibility that drug resistance and disease recurrence associated with imatinib treatment of CML can be avoided by targeting this essential stem cell maintenance pathway.

There is significant variation in the level of molecular responses achieved with imatinib therapy in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These differences could result from variable treatment adherence. Eighty-seven patients with chronic myeloid leukemia in chronic phase treated with imatinib 400 mg/day for a median of 59.7 months (range, 25–104 months) and who achieved a complete cytogenetic response had adherence monitored over a 3-month period using electronic micromonitoring. device. Adherence was associated with levels of molecular response. Other factors that could influence the outcome were also analysed. The median adherence rate was 98% (range, 24% to 104%). Twenty-three patients (26.4%) had adherence < or = 90%; In 12 of these patients (14%), adherence was <or=80%. There was a strong association between adherence rate (< or = 90% or > 90%) and the 6-year probability of a 3-log reduction (also known as major molecular response [MMR]) in BCR-ABL1 transcripts (28.4%) v 94.5%; P < .001) and also complete molecular response (CMR; 0% v 43.8%; P = .002). Multivariate analysis identified adherence (relative risk [RR], 11.7; P = .001) and expression of human molecular organic cation transporter-1 (RR, 1.79; P = .038) as the only independent predictors of MMR. Adherence was the only independent predictor of CMR. No molecular responses were observed when adherence was < or = 80% ( P < .001). Patients whose imatinib doses were increased had poor adherence (86.4%). In this latter population, adherence was the only independent predictor of inability to achieve MMR (RR, 17.66; P = .006). In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia who have been treated with imatinib for several years, poor adherence may be the predominant reason for the inability to obtain adequate molecular responses.

Imatinib, a selective BCR-ABL1 kinase inhibitor, has improved the prognosis of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). We performed efficacy and safety analyzes based on more than 10 years of follow-up in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia who were treated with imatinib as first-line therapy. In this open-label, multicenter, cross-over design trial, we randomly assigned patients with newly diagnosed chronic myeloid leukemia in the chronic phase to receive either imatinib or interferon alfa plus cytarabine. Long-term analyzes included overall survival, response to treatment, and serious adverse events. The average follow-up was 10.9 years. Given the high crossover rate among patients randomly assigned to receive interferon alfa plus cytarabine (65.6%) and the short duration of treatment before crossover in these patients (median, 0.8 years), the present analyzes focused on patients who received repeat therapy. They were randomly assigned to receive imatinib. Among patients in the imatinib group, the estimated overall survival rate at 10 years was 83.3%. Nearly half of the patients (48.3%) randomly assigned to imatinib completed study treatment with imatinib, and 82.8% had a complete cytogenetic response. The serious adverse events that researchers considered to be related to imatinib were uncommon and occurred most often during the first year of treatment. Approximately 11 years of follow-up showed that the effectiveness of imatinib was maintained over time and that long-term administration of imatinib was not associated with unacceptable cumulative or late toxic effects. (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals; IRIS ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00006343 and NCT00333840.).

The HER2 gene, which encodes the growth factor receptor HER2, is amplified, and HER2 is overexpressed in 25 to 30 percent of breast cancers, increasing tumor aggressiveness. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We randomly assigned 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) treatment with anthracyclines were treated with doxorubicin (or epirubicin in 36 women), cyclophosphamide alone (138 women) or trastuzumab (143 women). Patients who had previously received adjuvant anthracyclines were treated with paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel with trastuzumab (92 women). The addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with a longer time to disease progression (median, 7.4 vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001), a higher objective response rate (50% vs. 32%, P<0.001), and a longer response rate (50% vs. 32%; P <0.001). Duration of response (median, 9.1 vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), lower death rate at 1 year (22% vs. 33%; P=0.008), and longer survival (median survival, 25.1 vs. 20.3 months); P = 0.01), a 20 percent reduction in the risk of death. The most significant adverse event was New York Heart Association grade 3 or 4 cardiac dysfunction, which occurred in 27 percent of the group given anthracyclines, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab. 8% of the group were given anthracyclines and cyclophosphamide alone; 13% of the group were given paclitaxel and trastuzumab. 1% of the group was given paclitaxel alone. Although cardiotoxicity was potentially severe and, in some cases, life-threatening, symptoms generally improved with standard medical management. Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy in HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer.

Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), has been studied in combination with chemotherapy for the first-line treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. ToGA (trastuzumab for gastric cancer) was an international, open-label, phase III, randomized controlled trial conducted at 122 centers in 24 countries. Patients with gastroesophageal or gastroesophageal junction carcinoma were eligible for inclusion if their tumors showed increased expression of HER2 protein by immunohistochemistry or gene amplification by in situ hybridization. Participants were randomly assigned 1:1 to receive a chemotherapy regimen consisting of capecitabine plus cisplatin, fluorouracil plus cisplatin given every 3 weeks for six cycles, or chemotherapy in combination with intravenous trastuzumab. Allocation was by randomization stratified by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, chemotherapy regimen, extent of disease, site of primary cancer, and measurability of disease, which was implemented using a central interactive voice recognition system. The primary endpoint was overall survival in all randomized patients who received the study drug at least once. This trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01041404. 594 patients were randomly assigned to study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n = 298; chemotherapy alone, n = 296), of whom 584 were included in the primary analysis (n = 294; n = 290). Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11-25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9-25) in the chemotherapy alone group. Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12-16) in those assigned to trastuzumab plus chemotherapy compared with 11.1 months (10-13) in those assigned to chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio 0.74; 95% CI 0.60). 0.91; p=0.0046). The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] versus chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] versus 134 [46%]), and Neutrophils (157). [53%] versus 165 [57%]). Rates of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs. 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs. 18 [6%]) did not differ between groups. Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy may be considered a new standard option for patients with HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. F. Hoffmann-La Roche.

We present the pooled results of two trials that compared adjuvant chemotherapy with or without concurrent trastuzumab in women with surgically removed HER2-positive breast cancer. The National Adjuvant Surgical Breast and Bowel Project B-31 trial compared doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel every 3 weeks (Group 1) with the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab starting at the first dose of paclitaxel (Group 2). The North Central Cancer Treatment Group trial N9831 compared three regimens: doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by weekly paclitaxel (Group A), the same regimen followed by 52 weeks of trastuzumab after paclitaxel (Group B), and the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab initiated. In combination with paclitaxel (Group C). The studies were modified to include a combined analysis comparing groups 1 and A (control group) with groups 2 and C (trastuzumab group). Group B was excluded because trastuzumab was not administered concomitantly with paclitaxel. By 15 March 2005, 394 cases (recurrence, second primary cancer, or death before recurrence) had been reported, leading to the first scheduled interim analysis. Of these, 133 were in the trastuzumab group and 261 were in the control group (hazard ratio 0.48; P<0.0001). This result exceeded the limits of early stopping. The absolute difference in disease-free survival between the trastuzumab group and the control group was 12 percent after three years. Treatment with trastuzumab was associated with a 33% reduction in the risk of death (P=0.015). The three-year cumulative incidence of grade 3 or 4 congestive heart failure or death from cardiac causes in the trastuzumab group was 4.1 percent in trial B-31 and 2.9 percent in trial N9831. Trastuzumab combined with paclitaxel after doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide improves outcomes among women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00004067 and NCT00005970.)

Trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, has clinical activity in advanced breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We investigated its efficacy and safety after resection of early-stage breast cancer and completion of chemotherapy. This international, multicenter, randomized trial compared one or two years of trastuzumab given every three weeks with observational patients with HER2-positive, node-negative, or node-positive breast cancer who completed regional brachytherapy and at least four cycles of neoadjuvant or node-specific adjuvant. Adjuvant chemotherapy. Data were available for 1,694 women randomly assigned to 2 years of trastuzumab, 1,694 women assigned to 1 year of trastuzumab, and 1,693 women assigned to observation. We report here the results of only 1-year trastuzumab treatment or observation. In the first planned interim analysis (median follow-up of 1 year), 347 events (breast cancer recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, second non-breast malignancy, or death) were observed: 127 events in the trastuzumab group and 220 events in Note. group. The unadjusted hazard ratio of an event in the trastuzumab group, compared with the control group, was 0.54 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.67; P < 0.0001 by log-rank test, crossing interim limits of analysis), representing the absolute benefit in terms of survival. Disease-free life for two years increased by 8.4 percentage points. Overall survival in the two groups was not significantly different (29 deaths with trastuzumab versus 37 with observation). Severe cardiotoxicity developed in 0.5 percent of women treated with trastuzumab. One year of treatment with trastuzumab after adjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves disease-free survival among women with HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00045032.)

The clinical success of selective kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib and erlotinib, as therapeutic agents for many human cancers has generated significant interest in the further development and clinical testing of these inhibitors for a wide range of malignancies. While much of this effort has focused on tyrosine kinase receptors, including EGFR, HER2, PDGF receptor, c-KIT, and MET, serine/threonine kinase inhibitors are also beginning to emerge within discovery pipelines. Among these kinases, RAF and MEK kinases have received significant attention, largely due to their relatively high frequency of activating RAS mutations (about 20% of all human cancers), an upstream activator of the well-established RAF-MEK-ERK signaling cascade as well as mutations. Recurrent activation of BRAF kinase (about 7% of all human cancers). Here, we summarize the current state of development of kinase inhibitors directed at this signaling pathway, a few of which have already shown favorable toxicological profiles as well as promising activity in early-phase clinical studies.

Targeted therapies via compounds that inhibit a specific target molecule represent a new perspective in cancer treatment. In contrast to conventional chemotherapy, which acts on all dividing cells, leading to toxic effects and damage to normal tissues, targeted drugs allow to hit, in a more specific way, subsets of cells directly involved in tumor development. Molecules that control cell proliferation and death, such as receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) for growth factors, are among the best targets for this type of therapeutic approach. Two classes of compounds targeting RTKs are currently used in clinical practice: monoclonal antibodies and tyrosine kinase inhibitors. The era of targeted therapy began with the approval of trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against HER2, for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer, and imatinib, a small tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting BCR-Abl, in chronic myeloid leukemia. Despite initial enthusiasm for the effectiveness of these treatments, clinicians soon had to face the problem of relapse, as cancer patients almost always developed drug resistance, often due to activation of alternative RTKs pathways. From this perspective, the rationale for targeting drugs is undergoing a radical transformation. In the past, the main effort was aimed at developing highly specific inhibitors that act on individual RTKs. Now, there is general agreement that molecules that simultaneously interfere with multiple RTKs may be more effective than single targeted agents. With the recent approval by the US Food and Drug Administration of Sorafenib and Sunitinib—which target VEGFR, PDGFR, FLT-3, and c-Kit—a different scenario has emerged, as a new generation of anticancer drugs has emerged, capable of inhibiting more than one pathway. , will likely play a major role.

The evolving field of personalized medicine plays an increasingly important role in cancer prevention, diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment. Its importance in clinical management is demonstrated by the recent introduction into routine clinical practice of various individualized and molecularly targeted therapies with increased efficacy and/or reduced toxicity. Identifying cancer predisposition genes, such as the BRCA genes in breast cancer, allows screening programs to identify patients who are “at risk” for cancer and helps them make decisions about individual risk modification behaviors. Personalized medicine is also playing an increasingly important role in cancer treatment. It is increasingly clear that there are molecularly distinct subtypes of different common cancers, with different therapeutic approaches required for each subtype, for example, the use of monoclonal antibodies (trastuzumab and cetuximab) in HER2-positive breast and KRAS-positive colorectal cancer. cancer; Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib, gefitinib, erlotinib and crizotinib) in chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors and non-small cell lung cancer and intracellular agents (vemurafenib and olaparib) in metastatic malignant melanoma and ovarian, breast and prostate cancer. The effectiveness of different targeted therapies in such differentiated tumors suggests that we are entering an era in which treatment decisions are based on the tumor's molecular abnormality profile or “signature,” rather than the tumor tissue type or anatomical site of origin, improving patient prognosis and quality. from life. This mini-review focuses on the role of personalized medicine in cancer prevention and treatment as well as its future direction in oncology.

The strong clinical activity of imatinib and trastuzumab for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and breast cancer has demonstrated that blocking pathogenic tyrosine kinases can alter the natural history of human tumors. On the other hand, EGF receptor inhibitors showed generally modest activity. The inconsistency in the development of these agents means that both molecular target dependence and patient selection are essential for a successful outcome of this procedure. We will compare lessons learned from the development of Abl, c-Kit, HER2/neu (erbB2), and EGFR inhibitors, highlight successes and limitations in this area, and suggest new approaches for clinical development of tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy.

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, the two main types of chronic inflammatory bowel disease, are multifactorial conditions of unknown cause. The Crohn's disease susceptibility locus has been mapped to chromosome 16. Here we used a positional cloning strategy, based on linkage analysis followed by linkage disequilibrium mapping, to identify three independent associations with Crohn's disease: a frameshift variant and two missense variants for Crohn's disease. NOD2, which encodes a member of the Apaf-1/Ced-4 superfamily of apoptosis regulators that is expressed in monocytes. These NOD2 variants alter the structure of the protein's leucine-rich repeat domain or flanking region. NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kB; This activation function is regulated by the carboxy-terminal leucine-rich repeat domain, which has an inhibitory role and also serves as an intracellular receptor for components of microbial pathogens. These observations suggest that the NOD2 gene product confers susceptibility to Crohn's disease by altering the recognition of these components and/or by overactivating NF-kB in monocytes, thus documenting a molecular model of the pathogenic mechanism of Crohn's disease that can now be further developed. Investigation.

Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the gastrointestinal tract, which is thought to result from the influence of environmental factors in a genetically predisposed host. A gene located in the region surrounding the centromere of chromosome 16, IBD1, that contributes to susceptibility to Crohn's disease has been identified by multiple association studies, but the specific gene(s) have not been identified. NOD2, a gene that encodes a protein with homology to disease resistance gene products, is located in the linkage peak region on chromosome 16 (ref. 7). Here we show, using transmission disequilibrium testing and case-control analysis, that a frameshift mutation resulting from a cytosine insertion, 3020insC, which is predicted to encode a truncated NOD2 protein, is associated with Crohn's disease. Wild-type NOD2 activates the nuclear factor NF-kappaB, making it responsive to bacterial lipopolysaccharides; However, this induction was deficient in mutant NOD2. These results implicate NOD2 in Crohn's disease susceptibility and suggest a link between the innate immune response to bacterial components and disease progression.

Nod2 activates the NF-kappaB pathway after intracellular stimulation by bacterial products. Recently, mutations in Nod2 have been shown to be associated with Crohn's disease, suggesting a role for bacteria-host interactions in the etiology of this disorder. Here we show that Nod2 is a general peptidoglycan sensor by recognizing muramyl dipeptide (MDP), the minimal bioactive peptidoglycan motif common to all bacteria. Furthermore, the frameshift mutation 3020insC, the most common Nod2 variant associated with Crohn's patients, completely abrogates Nod2-dependent detection of peptidoglycan and MDP. Together, these findings impact the understanding of the progression of Crohn's disease. In addition, the characterization of Nod2 as the first pathogen-recognizing molecule that detects MDP will help unravel the known biological activities of this immunomodulatory compound.

Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs), Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, are chronic inflammatory disorders of the digestive tract. Tremendous progress has recently been made in understanding the pathogenesis of these diseases. By studying patients and mouse models, Crohn's disease has been shown to be driven by the production of interleukin 12 (IL-12) and interferon gamma (IFN-gamma), while ulcerative colitis is probably driven by the production of IL-13. A second area of ​​progress is identifying the specific genetic abnormalities responsible for the disease. The most important finding is the identification of mutations in the gene encoding the NOD2 (nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 2) protein in a subset of patients with Crohn's disease. Here, we discuss these recent findings and implications for treatment.

CARD15/NOD2 mutations are associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). CD and GVHD are suspected to be associated with dysfunction of Peyer's patches (PP) and isolated lymphoid follicles (LFs). Using a novel Card15/Nod2 knockout (KO) mouse model, we analyzed the effect of the gene on these lymphoid formations along with the development of experimental colitis. At weeks 4, 12, and 52, the numbers of PPs and LFs were higher in KO mice while no difference was observed at birth. At weeks 4 and 12, the size and cellular composition of PPs were analyzed by flow cytometry and immunohistochemistry. PPs from KO mice were larger with an increased proportion of M cells and CD4(+) T cells. KO mice were also characterized by higher concentrations of TNFalpha, IFNgamma, IL12 and IL4 measured by ELISA. In contrast, few differences were found in PP-null ileum and spleen of KO mice. Using chamber experiments, we found that this PP phenotype is associated with increased both cell permeability and yeast/bacterial translocation. Finally, KO mice were more susceptible to TNBS-induced colitis. Card15/Nod2 deficiency leads to abnormal development and function of PPs characterized by an exaggerated immune response and increased permeability. These observations provide a comprehensive link between the molecular defect and human CARD15/NOD2-associated disorders: CD and GVHD.

GATA3 is a transcription factor that regulates T cell production of cytokines. We studied the role of GATA3 in the development of colitis in mice. We performed quantitative polymerase chain reaction and immunofluorescence analyzes of colon tissue from patients with Crohn's disease (n = 61) or ulcerative colitis (UC, n = 74) or from patients without IBD (n = 22), to measure GATA3 levels. Colitis was induced by administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid to control mice, mice with T-cell-specific deletion of GATA3, and mice with deletion of tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) 1 and TNFR2 (TNFR double knockout). ); Some mice were given a GATA3-specific DNAzyme (hgd40) or control DNAzyme by intrarectal administration, or systemic injection of an anti-TNF antibody before or during the sensitization and challenge phase of colitis induction. Colon tissues were collected and immunohistochemical analysis was performed. Lamina propria mononuclear cells and T cells were isolated and analyzed by flow cytometry or cytokine assays. Colonic distribution of the DNA-labeled enzyme and inflammation were monitored by in vivo imaging (endoscopy) of mice. GATA3 messenger RNA levels were higher in colon tissue from patients with ulcerative colitis, but not ileal Crohn's disease, compared with control tissue; GATA3 levels correlated with levels of inflammatory cytokines (interleukin [IL] 9, IL17A, IL6, IL5, IL4, IL13, and TNF). We observed increased expression of GATA3 by lamina propria T cells from mice with colitis compared with controls. Mice with a T-cell-specific deletion of GATA3 did not develop colitis and their colon tissue did not produce inflammatory cytokines (IL6, IL9, or IL13). DNAzyme hgd40 inhibits the expression of GATA3 messenger RNA by unstimulated and stimulated T cells, and it is distributed throughout the inflamed colon of mice with colitis. Colon tissue from mice given hgd40 had reduced expression of GATA3 messenger RNA, compared with mice given the control DNA enzyme. Mice given hgd40 did not develop colitis after administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid; Lamina propria cells from these mice showed lower levels of IL6, IL9, and IL13 than cells from mice given the control DNA enzyme. Microscopic images revealed that hgd40 and anti-TNF reduced colitis over 3 days. hgd40 reduces colitis in TNFR double knockout mice. GATA3 levels are increased in patients with UC and are associated with the production of inflammatory cytokines in mice and humans. A DNA enzyme that blocks expression of GATA3 reduces colitis in mice, independent of TNF, and reduces cytokine levels in the colon. This DNA enzyme may be developed to treat patients with ulcerative colitis.

Geographic and ethnic differences in ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease recurrence suggest that environmental factors influence the risk of developing the disease. Prevention of helminths (parasitic worms) through improved hygiene may be one factor leading to increased spread of the disease. Parasitic worms alter the body's mucosal and systemic immunity. Animals exposed to helminths are protected from experimental colitis and other immune diseases, and helminth colonization can be used to treat persistent murine and human diseases. Helminths stimulate mucosal T cells to produce Th2 and regulatory cytokines. IL4, TGFbeta, and IL10 in helminth-induced mucosa are likely part of the protective process. Helminths affect innate immune pathways such as TLR4 expression and function. Helminths also induce various subsets of regulatory-type T cells in the gut that limit the growth and function of effector T cells. These effects of always-present helminths may have protected people from immune diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.

About 70 loci are associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD), particularly in innate immunity, autophagy, and pathogen recognition pathways. Phenotype and genotype associations are inconsistent. CD susceptibility polymorphisms ATG16L1 rs2241880, ICAM1 rs5498, IL4 rs2070874, IL17F rs763780, IRGM rs13361189, ITLN1 rs2274910, LRRK2 rs11175593, and TLR4 rs4986790 were reported in a Portuguese population (511 patients). with CD, and 626 controls) and were evaluated for their association with clinical characteristics of CD . There is a significant association between CD and single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in ATG16L1 (odds ratio [OR] 1.36 [1.15-1.60], P = 2.7 × 10(-6) for the G allele), IRGM (OR 1.56 [1.21]-1.93), P = 3.9 × 10(-4) for the C allele), and ITLN1 (or 1.55 [1.28-1.88], P = 4.9 × 10(-4) for the C allele). These SNPs are associated with ileocolic site (OR, respectively, 1.49, 1.52, and 1.70), ileocolic site (OR, respectively, 1.31, 1.57, and 1.68), and upper gastrointestinal tract involvement (OR, respectively, 1.31, 1.57, and 1.68). respectively for ATG16L1 and IRGM). , 1.96 and 1.95). The GG risk genotype in ATG16L1 is associated with patients responding to steroids (OR 1.89), responding to immunosuppressants (OR 1.77), and biologic therapy (OR 1.89). Both SNPs in ITLN1 and IRGM are associated with a positive response to biologic therapy. The risk of developing ileal, ileal, and upper gastrointestinal sites increased with the number of risk alleles (OR for three alleles, respectively, 7.10, 3.54, and 12.07); The odds ratio for a positive response to biological therapy is 3.66. A multilocus approach using autophagy-related genes provides insight into CD genotype-phenotype associations and genetic markers to predict therapeutic responses.

Schizophrenia is a highly genetic disorder. Genetic risk is conferred by a large number of alleles, including common alleles of small effect that can be detected by genome-wide association studies. Here we report a multi-stage, genome-wide study of the schizophrenia genome across 36,989 cases and 113,075 controls. We identified 128 independent associations covering 108 conservatively defined loci that meet genome-wide importance, 83 of which have not been previously reported. Correlations between genes expressed in the brain were enriched, providing biological plausibility to the results. Many of the findings have the potential to provide entirely new insights into aetiology, but the associations in DRD2 and several genes involved in glutamatergic neurotransmission highlight molecules of known and potential therapeutic relevance for schizophrenia, and are consistent with leading pathophysiological hypotheses. Independent of genes expressed in the brain, associations were enriched between genes expressed in tissues that have important roles in immunity, providing support for the predicted relationship between the immune system and schizophrenia.

In an effort to identify potential genetic risk factors for schizophrenia, research groups around the world have published more than 1,000 genetic association studies with largely inconsistent results. To facilitate interpretation of these results, we have created a regularly updated online database of all published genetic association studies of schizophrenia (“SzGene”). For all polymorphisms with genotype data available in at least four independent case-control samples, we systematically performed random-effects meta-analyses using allelic contrasts. From 118 meta-analyses, a total of 24 genetic variants in 16 different genes (APOE, COMT, DAO, DRD1, DRD2, DRD4, DTNBP1, GABRB2, GRIN2B, HP, IL1B, MTHFR, PLXNA2, SLC6A4, TP53, and TPH1) showed significant effects. Nominal significance with average summary odds ratios of about 1.23. Seven of these variables have not been analyzed previously. According to recently proposed criteria for evaluating cumulative evidence in genetic association studies, four of the important findings can be described as showing “strong” epidemiological validity. Our project represents the first comprehensive online resource of systematically synthesized and collated evidence for genetic association studies in schizophrenia. As such, it can serve as a model for field summaries of genetic associations in common and genetically complex disorders.

Although changes in nucleotide sequences that affect the conformation and structure of proteins are well known, functional changes resulting from nucleotide substitutions cannot always be inferred from simple analysis of DNA sequences. Because a strong bias for synonymous codon usage has been detected in the human DRD2 gene, suggesting selection at synonymous positions, through the relative independence of the G+C content of third codon positions from equal G+C frequencies, we chose to study the functional effects of the six synonymous changes. Known naturally occurring genes (C132T, G423A, T765C, C939T, C957T, and G1101A) in human DRD2. We report here that some synonymous mutations in human DRD2 have functional effects and suggest a novel genetic mechanism. 957T, rather than being “silent,” altered the expected mRNA folding, led to a decrease in mRNA stability and translation, and significantly altered dopamine-induced regulation of DRD2 expression. 1101A did not show an effect per se but abolished the above-mentioned effects of 957T in the 957T/1101A compound clone, demonstrating that combinations of synonymous mutations can have functional consequences radically different from those of each isolated mutation. C957T was found in linkage disequilibrium in European-American populations with -141C Ins/Del and TaqI 'A' variants, which have been reported to be associated with schizophrenia and alcoholism, respectively. These findings question some of the assumptions made about synonymous variation in molecular population genetics and genetic mapping studies of diseases with complex inheritance, and suggest that synonymous variation can have effects of potential pathophysiological and pharmacological importance.

- The A1 allele of the Taq I polymorphism of the dopamine D2 receptor (DRD2) gene was previously reported to be present in 69% of alcoholics, compared to 20% of controls. Other research has reported no significant difference in the prevalence of the A1 allele in alcoholics compared to controls and no evidence that the DRD2 gene is associated with alcoholism. We hypothesized that these apparently conflicting results may be because increases in the prevalence of the A1 allele may not be specific to alcoholism. Thus, we examined other disorders frequently associated with alcoholism or those thought to involve defects in dopaminergic neurotransmission. -Comparative case study. To minimize the effect of racial differences in gene frequencies, the study was limited to non-Hispanic whites. - Ambulatory patients and hospital patients. -Among all known controls (n = 314), 77 (24.5%) carried the A1 allele. Of the 69 controls known to be nonalcoholic, 10 (14.5%) carried the A1 allele. The prevalence of the A1 allele was significantly increased in patients with Tourette syndrome (44.9%, n = 147), attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (46.2%, n = 104), autism (54.5%, n = 33), and alcoholism ( 42.3%), n = 104), and PTSD (45.7%, n = 35). After correcting for multiple comparisons (requiring P less than 0.0009 for significance), all remained significant except for PTSD. The prevalence of the A1 allele was not significantly increased in patients with depression, panic attacks, Parkinson's disease, or obesity. The prevalence of the A1 allele in drug addiction and schizophrenia was only significant when compared with the nonalcoholic control group, and no correction for multiple comparisons was performed. These results indicate that the A1 allele of the DRD2 gene is associated with a number of behavioral disorders in which it may act as a modifier rather than as an underlying causative factor.

Cardiofacial Velo syndrome (VCFS), a syndrome characterized by an increased frequency of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, is associated with a small interstitial deletion of chromosome 22q11. We evaluated 50 adults with VCFS using a structured clinical interview (Clinical Evaluation Schedules in Neuropsychiatry or Psychiatric Evaluation Schedule for Adults with Developmental Disabilities if IQ <50) to establish a DSM-IV diagnosis. The schizophrenia phenotype of individuals with VCFS and schizophrenia was compared with a matched series of individuals with schizophrenia and without VCFS (n = 12). The King's Schizotypy Questionnaire was administered to individuals with VCFS (n = 41), their first-degree relatives (n = 68), and a series of unrelated normal controls (n = 316). All individuals with a VCFS deletion for the N25 probe (n = 48) were genotyped for a genetic polymorphism in the COMT gene that results in differences in enzymatic activity. Fifteen subjects with VCFS (30%) had a psychotic disorder, with 24% (n = 12) meeting DSM-IV criteria for schizophrenia. In addition, 6 (12%) had major depression without psychotic features. Individuals with schizophrenia had fewer negative symptoms and had a relatively later age of onset compared with those with schizophrenia and without VCFS. We found no evidence that possession of the low-activity COMT allele was associated with schizophrenia in our sample of individuals with VCFS. The high prevalence of schizophrenia in this group suggests that chromosome 22q11 may contain a gene or genes relevant to the etiology of schizophrenia in the general population.

It has been common for psychiatric research, including the search for predisposing genes, to proceed on the assumption that schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are two separate disease entities with different underlying etiologies. These represent Emil Kraepelin's traditional binary classifications of so-called “functional” psychosis and form the basis of modern diagnostic practice. However, emerging findings from many areas of psychiatric research do not fit well into this model. In particular, the pattern of findings emerging from genetic studies shows increasing evidence of overlap in genetic susceptibility across traditional classification categories – including association findings in DAOA(G72), DTNBP1 (dysbindin), COMT, BDNF, DISC1, and NRG1. Emerging evidence suggests that there may be relatively specific relationships between genotype and psychopathology. For example, DISC1 and NRG1 may confer susceptibility to a form of the disease with mixed features of schizophrenia and mania. Elucidation of genotype-phenotype relationships is still at an early stage, but the current findings highlight the need to consider alternative approaches to classification and conceptualization for psychiatric research rather than continuing to rely heavily on the traditional Kraepelinian dichotomy. As psychosis susceptibility genes are identified and characterized over the next few years, this will have a major impact on our understanding of the pathophysiology of the disease and lead to changes in the classification and clinical practice of psychiatry.

Heterogeneity in phenotypic manifestations and inconsistent genetic associations in mental illness remains a major challenge in molecular psychiatry. Recently, it has become increasingly clear that altered promoter DNA methylation can play a critical role in mediating differential regulation of genes and in facilitating short-term adaptation in response to the environment. Here, we report the investigation of the differential activity of membrane-bound catechol-O-methyltransferase (MB-COMT) due to variable promoter methylation and the nature of the contribution of the COMT Val158Met polymorphism as risk factors for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder through an analysis of 115 cases. Postmortem brain samples from the frontal lobes. These studies are the first to reveal that MB-COMT promoter DNA is often hypomethylated in patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, compared with controls (methylation rate: 26 and 29 vs. 60%; P = 0.004 and 0.008, respectively), Especially in the left frontal lobe (methylation rate: 29 and 30 vs. 81%; P = 0.003 and 0.002, respectively). Quantitative gene expression analyzes showed a corresponding increase in transcript levels of MB-COMT in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder patients compared with controls ( P = 0.02) with an accompanying inverse relationship between MB-COMT and DRD1 expression. Furthermore, there was a tendency for the Val allele to be enriched for the COMT Val158Met polymorphism with MB-COMT hypomethylation in patients. These results suggest that overexpression of MB-COMT due to promoter hypomethylation and/or a hyperactive allele of COMT may increase prefrontal dopamine degradation providing a molecular basis for the shared symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

We used a translational convergent functional genomics (CFG) approach to identify and prioritize genes involved in schizophrenia, through gene-level integration of genome-wide association study data with other gene and epigenetic expression studies in humans and animal models. Using multiple evidence scoring and pathway analyses, we identify the top genes (DISC1, TCF4, MBP, MOBP, NCAM1, NRCAM, NDUFV2, RAB18, as well as ADCYAP1, BDNF, CNR1, COMT, DRD2, DTNBP1, GAD1, GRIA1, GRIN2B, HTR2A, NRG1, RELN, SNAP-25, TNIK), brain development, myelination, cell adhesion, glutamate receptor signaling, G-protein-coupled receptor signaling and cAMP-mediated signaling as key to pathophysiology and as targets for therapeutic intervention. Overall, the data are consistent with a model of dysfunctional connectivity in schizophrenia, resulting from the effects of neurodevelopmental environmental stress on a background of genetic vulnerability. In addition, we show how top candidate genes identified by CFG can be used to generate a genetic risk prediction score (GRPS) to aid in the diagnosis of schizophrenia, with predictive power in independent populations. The GRPS also distinguishes between the classic age of onset of schizophrenia, early illness, and late illness. We also show, in three independent cohorts, two European Americans and one African American, increased overlap, reproducibility, and consistency in findings from single nucleotide polymorphisms to genes, then genes prioritized by the CFG, and ultimately at the level of biological pathways and mechanisms. Finally, we compared the top candidate genes for schizophrenia from this analysis with the top candidate genes for bipolar disorder and anxiety disorders from our previous CFG analyses, as well as results from the autism and Alzheimer's domains. Overall, our work maps the genomic and biological landscape of schizophrenia, providing leads toward better understanding of the disease, diagnosis, and treatment. It also reveals significant genetic overlap with other major psychiatric disorder domains, suggesting a need for improved nosology.

The fine-tuning of neural connections during development is regulated by environmental interactions. Some fine-tuning occurs through changes in gene expression and/or DNA methylation states of epigenetic genes. DNA methylation occurs by transferring a methyl group from S-adenosyl methionine to a cytosine residue in the CpG dinucleotide sequence. Although CpG sequences scattered throughout the genome are usually highly methylated, those occurring in CpG islands in the promoter regions of genes are less methylated. In most cases, the extent of DNA methylation correlates with the extent of gene inactivation. Other known epigenetic mechanisms include histone deacetylation and chromatin remodeling, RNA inactivation, RNA modification, and DNA rearrangements. Exposure memory expressed as epigenetic DNA modifications allows genetic plasticity and short-term adaptation of each generation to its environment. Environmental factors that affect DNA methylation include diet, proteins, medications, and hormones. The induced methylation changes may lead to an altered epigenetic response upon subsequent hormonal stimulation. The DNA methylation status of genes may be maintained as they transition through mitosis and meiosis. An increasing amount of data suggests a role for DNA methylation in multifactorial psychiatric disorders. For example, treatment with methionine can exacerbate psychosis; While valproate, a drug that produces hypomethylated DNA, reduces these symptoms. Hypermethylation in the promoter region of the RELN gene is associated with decreased gene expression. The protein of this gene reelin, which is essential for neuronal migration and synaptogenesis, is reduced in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, suggesting hypermethylation of the promoter region in these disorders. Some evidence suggests methylation of the promoter regions of the DRD2 and HTR2A genes in schizophrenia and mood disorders as well. DNA methylation typically increases with age, although hypomethylation in the promoter region of the A4 amyloid precursor gene during aging may play a role in Alzheimer's disease. Further studies are needed to determine the role of methylomes and other epigenetic phenomena in the nervous system.

No specific gene has been identified for any major psychiatric disorder, including schizophrenia, although there is strong evidence supporting the genetic basis of these complex and devastating disorders. There are several possible reasons for this failure, ranging from poor study design with low statistical power to genetic mechanisms such as polygenic inheritance, epigenetic interactions, and pleiotropy. Most currently used study designs are inadequate to uncover these mechanisms. However, to date, genetic studies have provided some valuable insights into the causes and potential treatments for psychiatric disorders. There is a growing body of evidence suggesting that understanding the genetic etiology of psychiatric diseases, including schizophrenia, will be most successful with integrative approaches that take genetic and epigenetic factors into account. For example, several genes including those encoding dopamine receptors (DRD2, DRD3, and DRD4), serotonin receptor 2A (HTR2A) and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) have been implicated in the etiology of schizophrenia and related disorders through... Meta-analyses and meta-analyses. Large, multicenter studies. There is also increasing evidence for the role of DRD1, NMDA (GRIN1, GRIN2A, and GRIN2B), brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), and dopamine transporter (SLC6A3) receptor genes in both schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Recent studies have indicated that epigenetic modification of the reelin (RELN), BDNF, and DRD2 promoters confers susceptibility to clinical psychiatric conditions. Pharmacological treatment of psychiatric disorders is likely to be more effective once the molecular pathogenesis is known. For example, hypoactive alleles of DRD2 and hyperactive alleles of COMT, which degrades dopamine in the synaptic cleft, are associated with schizophrenia. It is likely that insufficient dopamine transmission in the frontal lobe plays a role in the development of the negative symptoms associated with this disorder. Antipsychotic treatments with partial action on dopamine D2 receptors may be a reasonable alternative to current treatments and will be effective in reducing symptoms in individuals with psychosis. Treatments using dopamine D1/D2 receptor agonists or COMT inhibitors may also be beneficial for patients with negative symptoms in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The complex etiology of schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders calls for consideration of both genetic and epigenetic systems and careful design of experiments to illuminate the genetic mechanisms that confer responsibility for these disorders and to inform current and new treatments.

ZNF804a was identified through a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in which a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP rs1344706) in ZNF804a reached genome-wide statistical significance for association with a combined diagnosis of schizophrenia (SZ) and bipolar disorder. Although the molecular function of ZNF804a is unknown, its amino acid sequence is predicted to contain a C2H2-type zinc finger domain and suggests that ZNF804a plays a role in DNA binding and transcription. Here, we confirm that ZNF804a directly contributes to transcriptional control by regulating the expression of several SZ-associated genes and directly interacts with chromatin proximal to the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, the two genes that we find regulated by ZNF804a. Using immunohistochemistry, we demonstrated that ZNF804a localized to the nuclei of rat neural progenitor cells in culture and in vivo. We demonstrated that expression of ZNF804a results in a significant increase in transcript levels of PRSS16 and COMT, compared to GFP-transfected controls, and a statistically significant decrease in the transcript levels of PDE4B and DRD2. Furthermore, we show using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays that both epitope-tagged and endogenous ZNF804a directly interact with the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, suggesting direct transcriptional regulation by ZNF804a on the expression of these genes. These results are the first to confirm that ZNF804a regulates the transcription levels of four SZ-associated genes, and binds to the proximal chromatin of the promoters of two SZ genes. These results suggest a model where ZNF804a can modulate a transcriptional network of SZ-associated genes.

More than 70 mutations in the two structural genes for procollagen type I (COL1A1 and COL1A2) have been found in bands affected with osteogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disease in children characterized by fragility of bone and other tissues rich in type I collagen. Mutations include deletions, insertions, RNA splicing mutations, and single-base substitutions that convert a glycine codon to an amino acid codon with a larger side chain. With some exceptions, the most severe disease phenotypes are largely explained by the synthesis of structurally defective proα chains of type I procollagen that either interfere with triple helix folding or with self-assembly of collagen into fibrils. The results underscore how the zipper-like folding of the collagenous triple helix and the self-assembly of collagen fibrils depend on the principle of nuclear growth where a few subunits form a core and then the core is propagated to generate a large structure with a well-defined structure. The principle of nucleated growth is a highly efficient mechanism for the assembly of large structures, but biological systems that rely heavily on nucleated growth are highly vulnerable to mutations that cause the synthesis of structurally abnormal but partially functional subunits. Recently, several mutations in three other collagen genes (COL2A1, COL3A1, and COL4A5) have been found in probands with genetic diseases involving tissues rich in these collagens. Most test for rare genetic diseases but a few appear to have phenotypes that are difficult to distinguish from more common disorders such as osteoporosis, osteopenia, and aortic aneurysm. Therefore, the results suggest that mutations in procollagen genes may cause a wide range of rare and common human diseases.

Immunosuppressants are critical in preventing adverse immune reactions associated with allogeneic organ transplantation, but they often cause adverse effects in a number of biological systems, including the skeletal system. The calcineurin inhibitors FK506 and cyclosporin A inhibit nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) and induce potent immunosuppression. Among the NFAT proteins, NFATc1 is essential for the differentiation of bone-resorbing osteoblasts. Here we show that FK506 administration results in reduced bone mass despite blockade of osteogenic differentiation. This reduction is caused by a severe impairment of bone formation, suggesting that NFAT transcription factors also have an important role in the transcriptional program of bone cells. Indeed, bone formation is inhibited in Nfatc1- and Nfatc2-deficient cells as well as in osteoblasts treated with FK506. Overexpression of NFATc1 induces Osterix-dependent activation of the Col1a1 promoter (encoding type I collagen), but not Runx2-dependent activation of the Bglap1 promoter (encoding osteocalcin). NFAT and Osterix form a complex that binds to DNA, and this interaction is important for the transcriptional activity of Osterix. Thus, NFAT and Osterix cooperatively control osteoclast bone formation. These findings may provide important insight into the management of post-transplant osteoporosis as well as a new strategy to promote bone regeneration in osteoporosis.

Osteoporosis is a common disease with a strong genetic component. We previously described a polymorphic Sp1 binding site in the COL1A1 gene that has been associated with osteoporosis in several populations. Here we explore the molecular mechanisms underlying this association. A meta-analysis showed significant associations between COL1A1 “s” alleles and bone mineral density (BMD), body mass index (BMI), and osteoporotic fractures. The association with fracture was stronger than expected based on observed differences in bone mineral density (BMD) and body mass index (BMI), suggesting an additive effect on bone strength. Gel shift assays showed increased binding affinity of the “s” allele for the Sp1 protein, and primary RNA transcripts derived from the “s” allele were approximately three times more abundant than transcripts derived from the “S” allele in “Ss” heterozygotes. Collagen produced from cultured bone cells from Ss heterozygotes had an increased proportion of alpha1(I) protein compared to alpha2(I) protein, and this was accompanied by an increased proportion of COL1A1 mRNA relative to COL1A2. Finally, the yield strength of bone derived from “Ss” individuals was reduced when compared to bone derived from “SS” individuals. We conclude that the COL1A1 Sp1 polymorphism is a functional genetic variant that leads to osteoporosis through complex mechanisms involving alterations in bone mass and bone quality.

Type I collagen is the most abundant and ubiquitously distributed family of collagenous proteins. It is a heterodimeric complex comprising two alpha1(I) chains and one alpha2(I) chain which are encoded by the unlinked loci COL1A1 and COL1A2, respectively. Mutations at these sites primarily lead to connective tissue disorders, osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome types VIIA and VIIB. Two cases of osteoporosis and one case of Marfan syndrome are also the result of mutations at these sites. Mutation data can be accessed on the World Wide Web at http://www.le.ac.uk/depts/ge/collagen/collagen.html

Celiac disease is a genetically determined chronic inflammatory disease caused by an environmental precipitant, gluten. Patients with this disease may mainly suffer from non-gastrointestinal symptoms, as a result of which patients turn to various medical practitioners. Epidemiological studies have shown that celiac disease is very common and affects about 1 in 250 people. This disease is associated with an increased incidence of osteoporosis, infertility, autoimmune diseases, and malignant diseases, especially lymphomas. The mechanism of the intestinal immune response is not entirely clear, but involves a restricted immune reaction to HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 T cells in the lamina propria as well as an immune reaction in the intestinal epithelium. An important component of the disease is intraepithelial lymphocytes that may expand clonally in resistant flies and enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Studying the mechanism of the immune response in celiac disease can provide insight into the mechanism of inflammatory and autoimmune responses and lead to innovations in treatment.

Until a few years ago, celiac disease (CD) was thought to be a rare food intolerance limited to childhood and characterized by severe malabsorption and flattened intestinal mucosa. Currently, CD is a common autoimmune disorder in the general population (affecting 1 in 100 individuals), with onset at any age and with a variety of possible presentations. Identifying CD is difficult because it can begin not only with diarrhea and weight loss but also with atypical gastrointestinal (constipation, recurrent abdominal pain) and extraintestinal symptoms (anaemia, elevated transaminases, osteoporosis, recurrent miscarriage, aphthous stomatitis and associated of autoimmune diseases). disorders), or it can be completely asymptomatic. Over the past 20 years, the diagnostic accuracy of CD serology has gradually increased with the development of highly reliable tests, such as detection of tissue transglutaminase IgA, antibodies to the antioxidant gliadin peptide, and IgG. The routine use of antibody markers has allowed researchers to detect a very large number of “borderline” cases, characterized by positive serological results and mild intestinal lesions or normal small intestine architecture, which can be classified as possible CD. Therefore, it is clear that “old celiac disease” with flat mucosa is only part of the CD spectrum. It is possible that serums could identify CD in its early stages, before severe intestinal damage develops. In cases where serological tests are positive but with mild or absent intestinal lesions, detection of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 can help reinforce or rule out the diagnosis of gluten sensitivity.

Celiac disease is a lifelong intolerance to gluten found in wheat, barley and rye, and some patients are allergic to oats as well. The disease is genetically determined, with 10% of first-degree relatives affected and 75% of monozygotic twins concordant. Among patients with celiac disease, 95% are human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 positive. Characteristically, the jejunal mucosa is damaged by a T-cell-mediated autoimmune response that is thought to be initiated by a 33-mer peptide fragment in A2 gliadin, and patients with this disorder have elevated levels of anti-endomycin antibodies and anti-transglutaminase antibodies in the tissues. Their blood. Celiac disease is one of the most important food intolerances that can be diagnosed, and with the advent of a simple blood test to detect cases, prevalence rates are thought to be around 1:100. Traditionally, the condition presents with malabsorption and failure to thrive in childhood, but this picture has now been overtaken by the more common presentation in adults, usually accompanied by non-specific symptoms such as fatigue, anaemia, disturbed bowel habit or after hypotension. the blood. Impact of bone fractures. Small bowel biopsy is essential for diagnosis and shows a characteristic flat appearance with crypt hypoplasia and epithelial infiltration with lymphocytes. Diet is key to management and a gluten-free diet effectively treats the condition. However, this commitment is lifelong and many supermarket aisles are effectively closed to individuals with celiac disease. Adherence can be monitored by measuring antibodies in the blood, which return to a negative state after 6-9 months. Patients with mild symptoms who are accidentally discovered to have celiac disease often ask whether it is necessary to adhere to the diet. Current advice is that adherence to the diet is essential to avoid long-term complications, which are mainly osteoporosis and small bowel lymphoma. However, the risk of these complications is greatly reduced in patients who follow a gluten-free diet.

Public concern about gluten has led to widespread demand for gluten-free foods, yet celiac disease remains largely underdiagnosed, and some confusion remains regarding optimal diagnostic practices. Small intestine histology is the gold standard for diagnosis. High-quality commercial enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for transglutaminase A and deaminized gliadin immunoglobulins A and G are sensitive screening tools, but approximately 10% of celiac disease are seronegative, and serological tests are unreliable in the very young, and in people Those already following a low-gluten diet, and those using immunosuppressive medications. HLA DQA and DQB genotyping to show that alleles encoding HLA DQ2 and DQ8 are absent almost excludes celiac disease. Confirmation of histological remission reduces the risk of subsequent complications, such as osteoporosis and cancer. Monitoring remission by unreliable serology. Because gluten is an exogenous antigen and is readily accessible to the small intestine, the immunopathogenesis of celiac disease is better understood than other MHC class II-associated diseases, such as type 1 diabetes. Therapeutic targets have been identified and drugs are being developed to complement or even replace the gluten-free diet. With increased awareness and non-dietary treatments, the diagnosis and treatment of celiac disease will be increasingly prominent in medical practice.

To investigate the role of IL-4 in vivo in allergic asthma, we developed a murine model of allergen-induced airway inflammation. Repeated daily exposure of actively immunized C57BL/6 mice to aerosolized ovalbumin (OVA) resulted in peribronchial inflammation and an increase in eosinophils and lymphocytes in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid. In IL-4-deficient (IL4 −/−) mice, treated in the same way, there were significantly fewer eosinophils in the BAL and significantly less peribronchial inflammation compared with wild-type mice. In this model, mast cell-deficient (W/Wv) mice developed a similar degree of BAL eosinophilia and peribronchial inflammation as wild-type mice, demonstrating that mast cell is not required for the induction of chronic airway inflammation. In contrast, BAL eosinophilia and airway inflammation were absent in OVA-treated MHC ClassII-deficient (B6.Aa-/-) mice that lack mature CD4 + T lymphocytes. In conclusion, these results suggest that IL-4 is a central mediator of allergic airway inflammation, regulating antigen-induced eosinophil recruitment into the airways via a T cell-dependent mechanism.

IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 are thought to have an essential role in the allergic response to asthma. Previous work assumes that the primary source of these cytokines is CD4(+) T(H)2 cells. However, more recent studies have suggested that other innate production of type 2 cytokines may be equally important. Nuclear cells are a novel population of IL-13-producing innate cells, which are essential for protective immunity in Nippostrongylus brasiliensis infection. Given this, we investigated the possible presence of nuclear cells and their functional importance in experimental allergic asthma. We generated Il4(+/eGFP)Il13(+/Tomato) dual reporter mice to study cytokine-producing cells during allergic inflammation. We adoptively transferred IL-13-producing innate cells to investigate their role in bronchial hyperreactivity (AHR). We have shown that allergen-triggered nucleated cells infiltrate the lung and constitute a major innate source of IL-13. CD4(+) T cells in the lung almost exclusively express only IL-13, whereas IL-4-producing T cells are restricted to draining lymph nodes. Intranasal administration of IL-25 or IL-33 induced IL-13-producing megakaryocytes in BAL fluid. Surprisingly, adoptive transfer of wild-type nuclear cells, but not Il13(-/-) nuclear cells, to Il13(-/-) mice, which are normally resistant to IL-25-induced AHR, restored bronchial resistance and infiltration. Lung cells. These findings identify nucleated cells as a new cell type in allergic lung inflammation and an innate source of IL-13 that can directly stimulate AHR in the absence of IL-13-producing CD4(+) T cells. These data highlight nuclear cells as an important new consideration in the development of future treatment for allergic asthma.

Asthma is a common respiratory disease characterized by variable airway obstruction caused by acute and chronic bronchitis. Associated phenotypes include bronchial hyperresponsiveness (BHR), elevated serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels, and positive skin tests to common allergens. Binding of interleukin-13 (IL13) or interleukin-4 (IL4) to the IL4 receptor (IL4R) results in the initial response of Th2 lymphocyte polarization. Both IL13 and IL4 are produced by Th2 cells and are able to induce isotype switching of B cells to produce IgE after exposure to allergens. These cytokines also share a common receptor component, IL4R alpha. We investigated five IL4RA single-nucleotide polymorphisms in a cohort of Dutch families ascertained by asthma testing. By considering the subjects and their spouses as an unrelated sample, we observed significant associations between atopy and asthma phenotypes with several IL4RA polymorphisms, including S478P and serum total IgE levels ( P = .0007). A significant genetic–genetic interaction was detected between S478P in IL4RA and promoter variation -1111 in IL13, which was previously shown to be associated with BHR ( P = .003). Individuals with the at-risk genotype for both genes were approximately five times more likely to develop asthma than individuals with both non-at-risk genotypes (P = .0004). These data suggest that variations in IL4RA contribute to higher serum total IgE levels, and that the interaction between IL4RA and IL13 significantly increases an individual's susceptibility to developing asthma.
