The three gene signatures of periostin, chloride channel annexin 1 (CLCA1), and Serpin β2 (SERPINB2) in the airway epithelial brush are used to classify asthma into high-TH2 and low-TH2 endophenotypes. Little is known about the utility of sputum genotyping as a molecular phenotyping method. We sought to determine whether genotyping in sputum cells could identify T(H)2-high and T(H)2-low asthma subtypes. In induced sputum cell pellets from 37 asthma patients and 15 healthy control subjects, PCR was used to profile gene expression of the epithelial cell signature of IL-13 activation (periostin, CLCA1, and SERPINB2), and Th2 genes (IL4, IL5, and IL13). ), and other genes associated with Th2 airway inflammation. Gene expression levels of CLCA1 and periostin, but not SerpinB2, were significantly higher than normal in the sputum cells of people with asthma. Expression levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 were also significantly increased in asthma patients and were significantly correlated within individual subjects. By combining the expression levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 into a single quantitative measure (“average T(H)2 gene”), 26 (70%) of the 37 asthma patients had T(H) 2- High asthma, which is characterized by severe asthma symptoms and increased eosinophilia in the blood and sputum. Mean values ​​of the TH2 gene tend to be stable when initial values ​​are very high or very low but fluctuate above or below the maximum height of T(H)2 when initial values ​​are average. Transcripts of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 can be easily detected in sputum cells of asthma patients, and their expression levels can be used to classify asthma into high-T(H)2 and low-T(H)2 endophenotypes.

Chitin is an essential structural polysaccharide for fungal pathogens and parasites, but its role in human immune responses remains largely unknown. It is the second most abundant polysaccharide in nature after cellulose, and its derivatives are widely used today for medical and industrial purposes. We analyzed the immunomodulatory properties of purified chitin particles derived from the opportunistic human fungal pathogen Candida albicans, resulting in selective secretion of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. We have identified NOD2, TLR9, and mannose receptors as essential fungal chitin recognition receptors for the induction of this response. Chitin reduces LPS-induced inflammation in vivo and thus may contribute to the resolution of the immune response once the pathogen is defeated. Fungal chitin also causes eosinophilia in vivo, enhancing its ability to induce asthma. Polymorphisms in specific chitin receptors, NOD2 and TLR9, predispose individuals to inflammatory conditions and dysregulated expression of chitinases and chitinase-related proteins, whose activity is essential for the generation of IL-10-stimulating innate chitin molecules in vitro, has also been linked to inflammatory conditions and asthma. Chitin recognition is therefore critical for immune homeostasis and likely has an important role in infectious and allergic diseases.

Interactions with microbial pathogens are critical for the maturation of the immune system. Nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 1 (NOD1) protein is a cytosolic receptor that senses a muropeptide found predominantly in Gram-negative bacterial peptidoglycan. NOD1 is located on chromosome 7p14-p15, a region that has been linked to atopy. Recently, NOD2 polymorphisms have been closely associated with atopy-related traits. Within a large German adult population (n = 1417), a case-control group for atopic eczema (n = 454), and a large cohort of parent-offspring triads with atopic eczema (189 triads), we evaluated 11 NOD1 polymorphisms for associations with atopic patterns. . Methods Subjects were classified through standardized questionnaires and interviews, skin examination, and blood IgE measurements. Genotyping was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time of flight mass spectrometry. Analyzes revealed a significant association between NOD1 haplotype and atopic eczema in the population-based cohort ( P = .004) and case-control group ( P = .003). Another NOD1 haplotype was associated with lower total IgE ( P = .008). In addition, significant associations with total serum IgE levels were observed for the rs2907748 ( P = .006), rs2907749 ( P = .012), and rs2075822 ( P = .018) polymorphisms. These polymorphisms were significantly associated with atopic eczema and asthma in familial association analyzes ( P = .001-.043). Seven polymorphisms showed significant transmission distortion of total IgE levels (P values ​​<.0001-.029). These data suggest that genetic variants within NOD1 are important determinants of atopy susceptibility.

Nucleotide and oligomerization domain-like receptors (NLRs) are highly conserved cytosolic pattern recognition receptors that perform critical functions in scanning the intracellular environment for the presence of infections, harmful substances, and metabolic disturbances. Sensing of these danger signals by NLRs leads to their oligomerization into large molecular scaffolds and rapid deployment of effector signaling cascades to restore homeostasis. While some NLRs function by recruiting and activating inflammatory caspases to inflammasomes, others trigger inflammation via alternative pathways including nuclear factor-κB, mitogen-activated protein kinase, and regulatory factor pathways. The critical role that NLRs play in development and physiology is demonstrated by their pronounced effects on human diseases. Mutations in the genes encoding NLRP3 or NLRP12 lead to hereditary periodic fever syndromes, while mutations in CARD15 encoding NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease or Blau syndrome. Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have identified a number of risk alleles involving NLR genes in a range of diseases including allergic rhinitis, multiple sclerosis, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, multibacillary leprosy, vitiligo, premature menopause, and osteoporosis. Loss of density in older women. Animal models have allowed the characterization of basic effector mechanisms in a number of conditions. In this review, we highlight the functions of NLRs in health and disease and discuss how characterization of their molecular mechanisms provides new insights into therapeutic strategies for managing inflammatory diseases.

In wealthy, developed parts of the world, there has been a steady and simultaneous increase in at least three groups of diseases: (1) allergies, (2) inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD; such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis), and (3) autoimmune (such as... Type 1 diabetes and multiple sclerosis). Because the medical world is so divided, it will be some time before the relationship between these increases is noticed and understood. There is now evidence that the concurrent increase in these immune dysregulatory diseases is at least in part due to dysfunction of regulatory T cells (Treg). This paper provides an overview of relevant work in each of these areas of medicine (although with a focus on allergic disorders), and concludes that increased Treg failure is a consequence of diminished exposure to certain microorganisms that are “old friends.” Because of its constant presence throughout mammalian evolution. These organisms, which include saprophytic mycobacteria, helminths, and lactobacilli, are recognized by the innate immune system as harmless and as adjunctive to Treg induction. Polymorphisms in components of the innate immune system, such as TLR2 and NOD2, appear to define subgroups of the population that will develop immune regulatory disorders when living in the modern environment. An additional role played by these “old friends” and Treg may be to maintain the levels of IL-10 secreting regulatory macrophages and antigen-presenting cells, which are depleted in asthma and Crohn's disease. These concepts lead to new treatments based on harmless organisms or their components. Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials have yielded some statistically significant results, and phase 2 trials are still in progress.

The action of tissue transglutaminase (TGase) on specific glutamine residues bound to protein plays a crucial role in many biological processes. Here we provide evidence for a novel role for this enzyme in HLA-DQ2 (and DQ8)-associated enteropathy and celiac disease (CD). Intestinal inflammation in CD is accelerated by exposure to wheat gliadin in the diet and is associated with increased mucosal TGase activity. This enzyme has also been identified as the main target of CD-associated anti-Indomysium autoantibodies, and is known to accept gliadin as one of its few substrates. We examined the possibility that TGase may be involved in modulating gliadin-specific T cell reactivity. This could establish a link between previous reports on the role of TGase in CD and the prevailing view of CD as a T-cell-mediated disorder. We found a specific effect of TGase on T cell recognition of gliadin. This effect was limited to gliadin-specific T cells isolated from intestinal CD lesions. We have demonstrated that TGase mediates its effect through a regulated and specific deubiquitination of gliadin. This immunoprecipitation creates an epitope that efficiently binds to DQ2 and is recognized by gut-derived T cells. The generation of epitopes via enzymatic modification is a novel mechanism that may be relevant to tolerance breaking and the initiation of autoimmune diseases.

Wheat, rye and barley proteins trigger celiac disease, a type of autoimmune disorder of the digestive system, in genetically susceptible people. Because the disease may be underdiagnosed, we estimated the prevalence of the disease and tested the hypothesis that serum antibody assays can be used to detect untreated celiac disease and that positive results are associated with specific HLA haplotypes. Serum samples were collected from 3654 students (age range 7–16 years) in 1994 and screened in 2001 for endogenous and tissue transglutaminase antibodies. HLA typing was also performed on stored blood samples. All people with positive antibodies were asked to undergo a small bowel biopsy in 2001. Of the 3,654 people, 56 (1.5 percent) had positive antibody tests, as defined in 2001. The results of the two antibody tests were identical to an extent big. As of 1994, none of the subjects had received a clinical diagnosis of celiac disease, but 10 who had positive tests for both antibodies in serum obtained in 1994 had received the diagnosis between 1994 and 2001. Of the other 36 subjects with tests Positive for antibodies who consented to undergo a biopsy In 2001, 27 people had evidence of celiac disease on the biopsy. Thus, the biopsy-estimated prevalence was 1 case in 99 children. All but two of the people with the antibodies had either the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotype. The prevalence of the combination of antibody positivity and HLA haplotype associated with celiac disease was 1 in 67. The presence of serum tissue transglutaminase and endogenous autoantibodies is suggestive of small bowel abnormalities suggestive of celiac disease. There is a good correlation between antibody positivity and specific HLA patterns. We estimate that the prevalence of celiac disease among Finnish schoolchildren is at least 1 case in 99 children.

The vast majority of patients who are wheat gluten protein intolerant due to celiac disease (CD) are human histocompatibility leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2(+), and the remaining few typically express HLA-DQ8. These two class II molecules are mainly responsible for presenting gluten peptides to gluten-specific T cells which are only found in the intestine of CD patients but not in controls. Interestingly, tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-mediated deglutaminase plays an important role in the recognition of this food antigen by intestinal T cells. Here we have used recombinant antigens to demonstrate that the intestinal T cell response to α-gliadin in adult CD focuses on two DQ2-restricted immunogenic peptides that overlap a seven-residue fragment of gliadin. We have shown that tTG converts glutamine residues within this fragment into glutamic acid and that this process is essential for T cell recognition. Gluten-specific T cell lines from 16 different adult patients responded to one or both of these deamidated peptides, suggesting that these epitopes are highly relevant to the pathogenesis of the disease. Binding studies showed that deamidated peptides showed increased affinity for DQ2, a molecule known to preferentially bind peptides and which contains negatively charged residues. Interestingly, modified glutamine is internalized into different pockets of DQ2 for different epitopes. These results suggest modifications to anchor residues lead to improved major histocompatibility complex (MHC) affinity, and altered conformation of the peptide-MHC complex may be a critical factor leading to T cell responses to gliadin and intolerance to oral gluten. CD.

Although prescriptions for a gluten-free diet to treat gastrointestinal symptoms in individuals who do not have celiac disease are increasing, there is little evidence to suggest that gluten is the culprit. The goals of this study were to determine whether eating gluten can cause symptoms in non-celiac individuals and to examine the mechanism. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled rechallenge trial was performed in patients with irritable bowel syndrome in whom celiac disease was ruled out and whose symptoms were controlled on a gluten-free diet. Participants received either gluten or placebo in the form of two slices of bread plus one bagel per day with a gluten-free diet for up to 6 weeks. Symptoms were assessed using a visual analogue scale and signs of intestinal inflammation, injury, and immune activation were monitored. A total of 34 patients (aged 29-59 years, 4 men) completed the study according to protocol. Overall, 56% had human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 and/or HLA-DQ8. Adherence to diet and supplements was very high. Of the 19 patients (68%) in the gluten group, 13 reported that symptoms were not adequately controlled compared with 6 of 15 (40%) who took placebo (P = 0.0001; generalized estimating equation). On the visual analog scale, patients were significantly gluten-free at 1 week for overall symptoms (P = 0.047), pain (P = 0.016), bloating (P = 0.031), satisfaction with stool consistency (P = 0.024), and fatigue. (p = 0.001). Antibodies to gliadin were not induced. There were no significant changes in stool lactoferrin, celiac antibody levels, hypersensitivity C-reactive protein, or intestinal permeability. There were no differences in any endpoint in individuals with or without DQ2/DQ8. There may be a “non-celiac gluten intolerance,” but no evidence of the mechanism has been elucidated.

Genomic typing for HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 was performed for 50 patients with dermatitis herpetiformis and 290 healthy blood donors. Genes encoding DQ (alpha 1*0501, beta 1*02) were carried by 43 (86%) patients and 72 (25%) controls. Of the remaining seven patients, six (12% of all patients) carried genes encoding the DQ dimer (alpha 1*03, beta 1*0302). These HLA associations are very similar to those observed in patients with celiac disease. We therefore conclude that dermatitis herpetiformis and celiac disease are associated with the same HLA-DQ alpha beta variant.

The role of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 heterodimer (DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201) in presenting gluten peptides to effector T cells has been well documented in celiac disease (CD). Because HLA-DQ2 is carried on DR3 haplotypes due to linkage disequilibrium, such haplotypes are more frequently encountered in patients with autoimmune diseases. This study analyzed 35 north Indian children younger than 15 years of age who were diagnosed with CD according to the ESPGAN criteria, which included histological changes in duodenal biopsies, clinical response to gluten withdrawal, and the presence of anti-endothelin antibodies. HLA class I and class II alleles were identified by PCR-specific primers, sequence-specific oligonucleotide probes, and reverse transcriptase molecular techniques. Statistically significant positive association of disease with HLA-DRB1*03 (94.2% vs. 22.1% in controls, chi(2) = 73.4, p = 7.54E-11), and negative association with DRB1*15 (chi(2) ) = 7.4 , p = 6.5E-03) and DRB1*13 alleles were observed. HLA-DQB1*0201 was observed in all 35 patients (100%), while the presence of DQ2 heterodimer alpha(0)beta(0) occurred in 97.1% of CD patients (31.4% in double dose, 65.7% in single dose) It revealed a significant deviation from healthy controls (chi(2) = 102.08, p = 7.56E-11). Further analysis revealed the involvement of several DR3+ve haplotypes with CD in Indians, of which A26-B8-DR3 was the most common DR3 haplotype among patients (34.28%, chi(2) = 40.57, p = 2.65E- 10) followed by Ax-B21-DR3 (11.4%) (chi(2) = 13.8, p = 2E-04) and the classic Caucasian haplotype A1-B8-DR3 (5.7%). The former two haplotypes are characteristic of Asian Indians and are involved in the development of CD. We conclude that the high-risk DR3 haplotypes that play a critical role in the development of CD are unique to Asian Indians. Detailed analysis of these haplotypes in Indian patients with autoimmune diseases may help in understanding the influence of other involved genes within the major histocompatibility complex.

From 1991 to 1998, we vaccinated 4835 neonates against hepatitis B virus (HBV) and monitored their humoral response to the recombinant vaccine. In a sample of 184 of these children, we studied the association between HLA class I and II genomic polymorphisms and humoral response to vaccine and the association between immune response and disease. A subgroup of 96 children also underwent HLA class III typing (C4A and C4B). Four levels of humoral response have been identified, each with peculiar major histocompatibility complex (MHC) restriction. Different HLA products appear to act as agonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02) or antagonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02, and HLA-DRB1(*)11, DQB1(*)0301) in lowering humorality. Response to hepatitis B virus vaccine. The group of responders was characterized by a lack of “non-responder” alleles rather than by the presence of specific “responder” alleles. Tolerance to hepatitis B virus peptides may have clinical implications and may be a marker in children who have a genetic risk for autoimmune diseases. In fact, many poor responders carried two to four HLA-DQ alpha beta variants leading to insulin-dependent diabetes and celiac disease. Two true non-responders suffered from allergies and two slow responders had transient episodes of hyperglycemia.

The possibility that genetic susceptibility to celiac disease (CD) is influenced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene polymorphisms has been repeatedly raised. To date, this has only been investigated in case-control studies and results have been contradictory. In order to avoid any potential ethnic mismatch between patients and controls, we approached this issue by studying 71 celiac families, establishing parental haplotypes and comparing CD haplotypes versus control haplotypes (so-called AFBAC or affected family controls). We used DNA-based approaches to screen HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 alleles, TNFalpha promoter polymorphisms, and TNFa and b microsatellites. A guanine to adenine polymorphism at position -308 in the TNFalpha gene promoter region was found to be associated with CD where the TNF-308A allele appeared significantly in frequency in CD haplotypes, and this was shown to be independent of the association between CD and DRB1 alleles. *0301,DQA1*0501,DQB1*0201. Our results suggest that at least one other gene, in addition to the known association of CD with HLA class II, has a susceptibility role to this disease. This must be either TNFalpha or another polymorphic gene at the telomeric end of the HLA class III region.

Multiple sclerosis is a common disease of the central nervous system in which the interplay between inflammatory and neurodegenerative processes usually results in intermittent neurological disorder followed by a progressive accumulation of disability. Epidemiological studies have shown that genetic factors are primarily responsible for the significant increase in disease recurrence in relatives of affected individuals, and systematic attempts to identify links in multiplex families have confirmed that variation within the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) exerts the greatest influence. Individual influence on risk. Modestly powered genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the identification of more than 20 additional risk loci and shown that multiple variants exerting modest individual effects have a major role in disease susceptibility. Most of the genetic architecture underlying susceptibility to the disease remains to be determined, and is expected to require analysis of sample sizes that exceed the numbers currently available for individual research groups. In a collaborative GWAS study including 9772 cases of European origin collected by 23 research groups working in 15 different countries, we replicated almost all previously proposed associations and identified at least 29 new susceptibility loci. Within the MHC we have refined the identity of the HLA-DRB1 risk alleles and confirmed that variation in the HLA-A gene underlies the independent protective effect attributable to the class I region. Immuneologically relevant genes are overrepresented among those genes close to the identified loci, especially T helper cell differentiation in MS pathogenesis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system in which a restricted cellular immune response is observed. In order to determine whether these T-cell responses are likely to be antigen-specific particularly with respect to myelin basic protein (MBP), we analyzed T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangements directly from MS brain plaques, using reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction. transcribed messenger RNA (RNA), and compared them with TCR clones for MBP-specific T cells described previously from an MS and experimental allergic encephalomyelitis murine model. Rearranged V beta 5.2 genes were detected in the brains of all patients with HLA DRB1*1501, DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401. Beta V beta 5,2-D beta-J sequences in MS brain plaques revealed five isoforms. One common element was identical to that described for the VDJ region of the V beta 5.2 T cell clone. This clone was from an MS patient that was HLA DRB1*1501, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401, and was cytotoxic toward targets containing the MBP peptide. 89-106 (Ref. 1). The deduced amino acid sequence of the VDJ rearrangement, Leu-Arg-Gly, has also been described in murine T cells cloned from experimental allergic encephalomyelitis lesions, which is specific for the MBP peptide 87-99 (ref. 2). VDJ sequences with this MBP loop specificity account for a significant fraction (40%) of TCR V beta 5.2(D)N rearrangements in MS lesions. The ability of rat T cells with these VDJ sequences to cause experimental allergic encephalomyelitis and the prevalence of such sequences in human demyelinated lesions suggest that T cells with rearranged TCRs may be critical in MS.

There is a striking gradient in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis (MS), but exceptions in Mediterranean Europe and northern Scandinavia, and some systematic reviews, suggest that the gradient may be an artifact. The authors sought to evaluate the relationship between MS prevalence and latitude through meta-regression. Studies were obtained from online databases, reference mining, and author referral. Prevalence estimates were age-standardized for the European population in 2009. Analyzes were performed by random-effects meta-regression, weighted with the inverse of the within-study variance. The authors included 650 prevalence estimates from 321 peer-reviewed studies; Of these, 239 were standardized by age, and 159 provided sex-specific data. The researchers found a significant positive association (change in prevalence by degree of latitude) between age-standardized prevalence (1.04, p<0.001) and latitude that diminished at higher latitudes. Adjusting for year of spread strengthened the association with latitude (2.60, p<0.001). The inverse gradient was reversed in the Italian region when adjusting for MS-associated HLA-DRB1 allele distributions. Adjusting for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies did not significantly change the gradient in Europe. Adjusting for some potential sources of bias did not affect the observed associations. This most comprehensive review of MS prevalence to date confirmed a statistically significant positive relationship between MS prevalence and latitude globally. The exceptions to phasing in the Italian region and northern Scandinavia are likely the result of genetic, behavioral and cultural differences. The persistence of a positive gradient in Europe after adjustment for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies strongly supports the role of environmental factors that vary with latitude, the most prominent candidates being ultraviolet radiation (UVR)/vitamin D.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex trait in which allelic variation in the MHC class II region exerts the strongest influence on genetic risk. Epidemiological data in MS provide strong evidence that environmental factors act at the population level to influence the unusual geographic distribution of this disease. Increasing evidence points to sunlight or vitamin D as a major environmental factor in its aetiology. We hypothesized that this environmental filter might interact with inherited factors and sought responsive regulatory elements in the MHC class II region. Sequence analysis identified a single MHC vitamin D response element (VDRE) to the promoter region of HLA-DRB1. Sequencing of this promoter in more than 1000 chromosomes of HLA-DRB1 homozygotes showed absolute conservation of the putative VDRE over HLA-DRB1*15 haplotypes. In contrast, there was striking variation among non-MS haplotypes. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific recruitment of vitamin D receptors to the VDRE in the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter, which was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments using lymphoblasts homozygous for HLA-DRB1*15. Transient transfection using a luciferase reporter assay demonstrated a functional role for this VDRE. B cells transiently transfected with the HLA-DRB1*15 gene promoter showed increased expression upon stimulation with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (P = 0.002) that was lost when the VDRE was deleted or with the homologous “VDRE” sequence found in non-HLA haplotypes. -DRB1 associated with MS. Flow cytometric analysis showed a specific increase in cell surface expression of HLA-DRB1 upon vitamin D addition only in lymphoblasts bearing HLA-DRB1*15. This study further points to vitamin D as a strong environmental candidate in MS by demonstrating direct functional interaction with a key locus that determines genetic susceptibility. These findings support a relationship between the main epidemiological and genetic features of this disease with major practical implications for studies of disease mechanism and prevention.

Throughout the usual LDL cholesterol range in Western populations, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, in such populations, reducing LDL cholesterol may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of initial cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40-80 years) with coronary artery disease, other arterial-occlusive disease or diabetes were randomly allocated to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily (median compliance: 85%) or placebo Matched (average statin use without study: 17%). ). Analyzes are first performed for specific events, comparing all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo. These “intention-to-treat” comparisons evaluate the effects of about two-thirds (85% minus 17%) taking a statin during the scheduled 5-year treatment period, which resulted in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (About two-thirds of the effect of actual use of 40 mg of simvastatin daily). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subgroup analyses), with subcategories for cancer and other major morbidity. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin assigned vs. 1,507 [14.7%] among 10,267 placebo assigned; P = 0.0003), due to a very significant relative reduction of 18%. (SE 5) in coronary mortality (587 [5.7%] vs. 707 [6.9%]; P = 0.0005), and a marginally significant reduction in other vascular deaths (194 [1.9%] vs. 230 [2.2%]; P = 0.07), and a non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality (547 [5.3%] versus 570 [5.6%]; P = 0.4). There were highly significant reductions of about a quarter in the first event rate for nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] versus 1212 [11.8%]; P < 0.0001), for nonfatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%]). vs 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001), and for coronary or non-coronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a significant 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19-28) reduction in event rate (2033 [19.8%] versus 2585 [25.2%] of affected individuals; p < 0.0001 ). During the first year, the reduction in major vascular events was not significant, but was subsequently very large during each separate year. The relative reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in every subgroup of participants studied, including: those who were not diagnosed with coronary artery disease and who had cerebrovascular disease, had peripheral artery disease, or They had diabetes; Men and women separately; Those aged 70 or over at entry; And - especially - even those with LDL cholesterol less than 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL), or total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefits of simvastatin were additional to those of other cardiac treatments. The excess annual risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or on hospitalization for any reason other than vascular. Adding simvastatin to existing therapies safely results in significant additional benefits for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the rates of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for non-compliance, actual use of this system would likely reduce these rates by about a third. Hence, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, taking simvastatin for 5 years would prevent about 70-100 people per 1000 from suffering at least one of these major vascular events (and longer treatment should to more benefits). The magnitude of the 5-year benefit is based primarily on these individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not on blood lipid concentrations alone.

Although treatment of myocardial overload effectively reduces death resulting from the development of heart failure, it is not known whether remission of progressive coronary artery disease resulting from lipid-lowering therapy will prevent the onset and consequences of heart failure in patients with no previous symptoms. For heart failure. In the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study, 4444 patients with coronary heart disease without evidence of heart failure were randomized to placebo (n = 2223) or simvastatin 20-40 mg (n = 2221) and followed for more than 5 years. Among patients who received placebo, 228 (10.3%) were diagnosed with heart failure during follow-up evaluation compared with 184 (8.3%) of patients who received simvastatin (P < .015). The mortality rate was 31.9% in the placebo group and 25.5% in the simvastatin group among patients who developed heart failure. These compare with 9.2 and 6.6%, respectively, among patients without heart failure. There were 45 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the placebo group and 23 in the simvastatin (NS) group. Patients who developed heart failure were more likely to have recurrent myocardial infarction and to have a history of diabetes, peripheral artery disease, and hypertension compared to patients who did not develop congestive heart failure. Long-term prophylaxis with simvastatin reduces the incidence of heart failure in a group of patients with coronary heart disease without previous evidence of congestive heart failure.
